div.em: Current conditions as of 26 Apr 15:56 pm CDT

div.span: Partly cloudy, with a low around 47. South wind 8 to 14 mph, with gusts as high as 20 mph.
Sunny, with a high near 78. South wind around 7 mph becoming north in the afternoon.

A chance of showers and thunderstorms before 4am, then showers likely and possibly a thunderstorm between 4am and 5am, then a chance of showers and thunderstorms after 5am. Increasing clouds, with a low around 54. East northeast wind 5 to 8 mph becoming south after midnight. Chance of precipitation is 60%. New rainfall amounts of less than a tenth of an inch, except higher amounts possible in thunderstorms.

h3.a: âSchoolâ is Much More Than Subject Content

span.span: It happens too often: we give up when life becomes too hard to bear. Weâve all faced these moments, whether big or small. And while COVID-19 didnât seem like a big threat to begin with, it quickly and drastically overhauled everyoneâs lives, including the lives of todayâs youth. Triumphantly, instead of giving up, my school and community have adapted just like countless others across our state and nation, and itâs safe to say we have developed a new appreciation for school and everyday life in the process.

As schools began closing, educators knew they needed to find a solution, and with todayâs technology, eLearning became an obvious answer for our high school. ELearning is learning thatâs computer and distance based. This allows students to continue their learning at home or at least keep an already learned concept active.

At a glance, eLearning doesnât seem that different from an actual school institution and even has some advantages. Seemingly, eLearning is more convenient for the students, guardians, and teachers. Itâs a great solution for social distancing and the COVID-19 epidemic weâre facing, and teachers are continually adapting in order to reach their students.

Jeff Bachman, a teacher at Leigh High School, said, âThis time has introduced me to some new technologies that I will continue even once we are back to normal.â In his Social Studies classes, Mr. Bachman has continued with his regular approach to teaching. He posts videos of himself teaching the new curriculum and assigns homework. Like all teachers, he then answers any questions via email or during his Zoom âoffice hoursâ where any student can join his Zoom meeting and receive face to face help or just say hello.Â

Our elementary school has taken a little different approach to distance learning, but the concept is still similar. Kim Loseke, Leigh Elementary School teacher, said, âIn third grade, we are sending a weekly packet of reading and math home for enrichment. We are going to start a weekly Zoom meeting, so we can stay connected as a class. It will be a time we can meet and share what weâve been up to at our homes or do something fun, like an indoor scavenger hunt.â
As proven, teachers are still working hard to provide for their students, and this connection goes beyond a simple education.

Leigh principal, Troy Holmberg, said, âSomething I have noticed from our teachers is the concern they have for students during this time. They want students to keep working, but they are more concerned about everyone making adjustments to everyday life during a crisis.â

From teachers to students, everyone is making the most of this new normal.Â Pre-schoolers are giving each other field trips to their bedrooms.Â Many high schoolers are keeping journals of the experience to share with their grandkids someday.Â Seniors are sitting at the table to do homework with elementary aged siblings, and in general, families have become stronger. Teachers are learning technology theyâve never used before.Â Cooks are preparing and sending out over 100 free lunches a day.Â Other support staff are getting an early jumpstart on deep cleaning and preparing to transition into our new school next year.Â Â

However, no matter what measures are being taken and what changes are being made, eLearning cannot truly replace âschoolâ in its broadest sense.Â What has really manifested itself during this shift to e-learning is that there is so much more to âschoolâ than trig functions, science experiments, and Shakespearean poetry.Â

While eLearning is a great solution to our problems now, itâs imperative that the traditional style of school stays alive in the future. It is clear now in these times of quarantine and social distancing, that what is so special about school is the relationships and comradery, even if we have taken them for granted in the past.Â .

Sophomore Makenna Held said, âIâve realized these past few weeks that school is not just a place for completing lessons and work, but also a place where students can be with their friends and laugh with their teachers. A place to share the joys of the week and also the lows. Life without school has had its own simple rewards of course, but it isnât as special. I have a new profound longing to get back and sit in the wooden desks and hear the bell ringing every hour. School may be a place we say we donât like, but until it is really gone, we donât know how much it actually means to us.â
Even Kindergartener Sophie Loseke said, âWe have no more school for this year. Thatâs sad. I like seeing my friends on Zoom, but I more prefer to see them at school.â

In a normal year, students anxiously and sometimes painstakingly tick down the days until the freedom of summer vacation.Â But this year, this extended COVID-19 âbreakâ has truly shown many students how valuable school is, especially since COVID-19 has ended the school year abruptly for many students. No one has experienced this bittersweet feeling more than the Class of 2020 seniors.Â Â
Leigh senior foreign exchange student, Hannah Dronsett, had not planned to have her Nebraska life uprooted without a momentâs notice when she was required to return home to Norway in mid-March.Â Â

âI had to end my exchange year three months early because of the coronavirus. My year is now over, and I basically have a five-month summer break. As both a foreign exchange student and a senior, it affects two things Iâve been dreaming of ever since I was little: prom and graduation. Iâm heartbroken my year had to be cut short, but my year in Leigh was, without a doubt, the best year of my life. Iâm sad I didnât get to say goodbye to so many people.â

Fellow senior Natalie Reeves said, âBeing a senior, I definitely didn't think my senior year would end like this. This national pandemic has brought something unimaginable for all of us. My last month and a half of âschoolâ has consisted of online learning, something I never thought we would resort to. Before COVID-19, I did dread going to school some days.Â What student doesnât?Â But now I would give anything to go to school again.Â I miss seeing my friends, classmates, and teachers. My classmates and I have been looking forward to graduation since the beginning of the school year, but now we don't know what graduation will even look like. COVID-19 has thrown many twists and turns in plans and memories for everybody, but after all of this, we will come out with a new perspective on life and learn not to take the little things for granted!"Â

We canât change the present situation; however, we can certainly change our attitude. Like all schools, everyone at Leigh has had to change, grow, learn, and adapt.Â Above all, weâve come to appreciate the simple things about life and school we have perhaps over time started to take for granted.Â Â

Mrs. Fischerâs 8th grade writing

did their March Madness Poetry competition online for the first time this year!Â Students submitted their videos to Flipgrid, and watched each other's videos each round and gave feedback.Â We are down to the Final Four and I will be asking staff members to help vote on the last two rounds!
Mrs. Brabecâs 6th graders
did a Vocab Jam at their weekly Zoom meeting. It's on the
vocab.com
website and I host a team competition on knowing the meaning of vocab words from the list.Â
Thank you
Brooke Koliha from ESU7
for presenting to our staff for vocabulary PD!! It was a great session!

div.p: Congratulations to the class of 2020.Â We appreciate everything you have been involved in throughout the years.Â Leigh Community Schools wishes you a bright future filled with an abundance of success.

h3.a: Leigh JR/SR High: Zoom Office Hours

span.b: Â Â Â Â LEIGH JR/SR HIGH: ZOOM OFFICE HOURS

span.span: Through the remainder of the school year, all Leigh Jr/Sr teachers will have virtual office hours throughout the school week via Zoom meetings. Teachers are sharing their meeting codes with the students. The Zoom meetings give our teachers and students the opportunity to interact face-to-face during our building closure.Â Each teacher has one hour set aside each day school is in session. Times are listed below. Individual teachers will also have additional Zoom meetings for specific courses at other times during the week.

We encourage students to utilize the office hour time to ask questions and share thoughts.Â We know it is not the same as being in the classroom together, but it does get us closer to that atmosphere.
If you have any questions regarding the remote learning program, including Zoom, contact Mr. Holmberg at the high school (402-487-2228) or by email (tholmberg@leigh.esu7.org)
